comments.commentBody: Josh - the increases in the VA budget over the last few years (starting in 2009) were due to President Obama's efforts to get Congress to allocate more.  The increase bartered in 2009 was higher than any in the previous 30 years.  The 10% increasse in 2011 (also asked for by Pres. Obama) raised he VA budget to $125 billion.  Even McCain was quoted in the press and on TV as praising Obama's work for veterans.

Share what Spanish culture? Some years ago I was in Caracas in a negotiation shortly after riots there. The Venezuelans there volunteered that the rioters were from Columbia. Language? Try asking a Castilian Spaniard what he thinks of Mexican Spanish. Cultural heritage? Check out what Argentines think of Bolivians. And back to common language-what about e.g. the Indians who live on the Alto Plano in Bolivia or in multiple places elsewhere. Paraguayans who also speak a separate language. And we can write off Brazilians who unfortunately speak Portuguese.

The categories need not expansion but complete dismissal, as they unnecessary. Who cares whether Rubio now claims to be white. For the Anglo-Saxons he will always be a Cuban American - of Spanish origin,

Eating qwichy instead of steak is too high a price to pay for high employment.

Oh, the French eat steak, do they? Hmm...
I changed from "other race" to "white" when I heard about the white-privilege thing... but it didn't work out, I still have to work to make a living...!!

This article is mistaken, I think, when it says that "Race is an immutable characteristic for many white, black and Asian-Americans." There are no objective criteria that assign anyone to a "race" in this country, nor  is there any scientific consensus about whether any such criteria actually exist. It is purely self-identification - so always mutable, for everyone.
I find the college students I work with absolutely recoil at these boxes to check and many of them do not even fit clearly into the given categories.  The opt out given a chance.
I'm a Black Hispanic and I believe you...this happened to me in a hospital in Baltimore when my son was born...

I remember when I was working for a health center that served a majority Hispanic population. I noticed in the charts that most Hispanics identified as white even if they were as dark as I am (Black). I noticed that the computer registration portal allowed you to list Hispanic white but no Black. In other words if you put Hispanic it had to be white or other. Black was never given as a choice.

It will never go away, but the categories on the census will continue to evolve, as they always have, for the next many decades and perhaps centuries. It would be interesting to see how the census form will ask for race a century from now. Or how about 500 years from now when there has been centuries of intermixing between distinct races, such as Japanese and African Americans, or whatever.

This doesn't surprise me. I am a health care provider at a major medical center where we have to follow ObamaCare protocol requiring that we record a patient's race and ethnicity for their electronic medical record.  Most offices make this assessment without asking the patient, but I make a point of asking patients directly so that they know that this is being done to them as a requirement of ObamaCare. Almost all Hispanics, no matter how dark, declare their race to be White (unless they are manifestly of African descent).  Given this trend, "Whites" will remain the majority race in the U.S., simply by virtue of encompassing most Hispanics.
I don't know about idiotic - it works probably for the majority of people. Of course it's too broad though.

And they don't even do a good job about it; I'm a black man from the Dominican Republic and I became a father two years ago. My son was born in Baltimore, MD and the day we were heading home this lady comes in to ask us a few questions (which I assumed was some sort of census survey).

So when she ask me to identity my ethnicity I responded the same way I fill out the census form in 2010:"Hispanic" and she laugh kind of like saying "really...?" so I point out the next question which asked about "race" and I said "and there you write that I'm black"...and this lady was so confused about the whole thing... I had to explain to her that "Hispanic" is not a race and even then she didn't get it...

"Race is an immutable characteristic for many white, black and Asian-Americans."

No, no it isn't. *Skin color* and *facial features* are (somewhat) immutable. But "race" has always been a shifting notion based more on what racists would like to define as "other" than any true biological basis.

http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2013/05/what-we-mean-when-we...

While living and working in the U.S. for a few years, I found myself wondering about the race/ethnic classifications I encountered while filling out certain forms from time to time. I usually ended up marking the "Hispanic" box where present, or none if it wasn't there. Born and raised in the Dominican Republic -where most of the population has mixed racial origins with a strong African or black component-, I belong to the 15-20% of Dominicans who are routinely classified as the country's white minority. Yet, I would not mark "white", in the forms, ever. And honestly, if I had marked "black" I would have been stared at in disbelief. Hispanic/Latino seemed more fitting, even when the term is more of a cultural/linguistic than of an actual race in content. I am also acutely aware of how segments of the American academic establishment treat Dominicans as an "ethnicity in denial of its black roots". I have always found this rather shallow and based on plain ignorance, when not a simple derogatory extension of the infamous "one black blood drop rule" being enforced by certain agendas, visibly uncomfortable with an ethnic group that seems not to align with their dogmas on race and culture in strict black/white terms (anything in between, specially in such large numbers, is taboo). Coming from a place where there a many shades when it comes to skin color, I'd be careful to "judge". I firmly believe that ethnic-cultural identity trumps any interpretations about race.

"I hope that on the next census, everybody declares themselves "white" just to invalidate this ludicrous practice, since the whole idea of "race" is nothing more than a mythological crock anyhow."

Since when? As long as achievement gaps exist between white and non-white Americans, I'm sorry to inform you, race does matter. That's why the census collects this data in the first place. If everyone dismissed their racial identities in favor of some post-racial neutral construct, we would be unable to identify the groups that are being underrepresented or underserved. To dismiss race as an important part of someone's reality and identity is to say "we have no need to recognize the particular needs and challenges of your community."

Only 95% of the native american population died off in the Caribbean region in the first 25 years after the discovery/conquest of America. Same proportion in South America, only more gradually, in 100 years. In the Caribbean region the native american population never recovered from the demographic catastrophe (the islands were repopulated with forced migrants from Africa, as labor hands were needed). In South America the native american population gradually recovered, but never to the pre-conquest levels. Pretty shocking.

Hispanics can be of any race and combination thereof. I filled out white because I am white,my ancestors were once european immigrants BUT I identify myself POLITICALLY as hispanic or latina(i don't like using latina unless I'm speaking Spanish because it sounds like spanglish)
I am very aware of being discriminated against even if it takes people a while to know for sure what I am.

Hispanics don't have to "pass" for anything except in the USA where the race card speaks and race trumps culture and language.

What is the race of an English speaking north-American?

Exactly,I was born in Uruguay,my ancestors came from Spain,Portugal,Italy,France and Germany. This is not a biological definition of caucasian(or black or native) is a political label. It's a way to keep people apart. Us vs them. Politics are always divisive,it's a means of control of masses.
I like that suggestion,mine is dulce de leche!

the point \we're making is that your ancestors could have even been "anglo-saxon-northern-european" stock but they too a little longer boat ride down south so now you are not white but hispanic. The affirmative action advantages are myths. i always hear about them but I don't know anyone who benefited from them. Same thing for those benefits for people with disabilities. ALL this discussion is POLITICAL not factual.

"Research suggests that Hispanics who have experienced discrimination are less likely to identify as white."

In simpler language, the self-identification is largely a measure of degree of assimilation and access to white privilege. Makes sense to me.
…because it's political

There are two questions on those applications (and on the census):

a. Are you Hispanic? (yes or no)

b. What is your race? (black, white, asian, other)

So applicants can be both Hispanic and White, thus benefitting simultaneously from "affirmative action" AND "white privilege."

Quite the best place to be!

I remember several Latin news stations were telling Hispanics and Latinos to identify as white in the census because there was so much confusion about what to answer for the race question. One news station even said that that's what people were told to do when they called up the census to ask that question.
